Show HN: I'm using Midjourney to create reward images for my word game Xordle
text: I'm using Midjourney to solve a game design issue I had with my Wordle variant, Xordle, where it was fun to have themed puzzles but the themes tended to either be too hard to notice even after the puzzle was completed (missed opportunity for a fun moment for most players), or too easy to notice before the puzzle was completed (giving away the answer). It requires a little effort to generate prompts, but not too much; definitely worth it in this case as I can now do themes that are pretty vague and are revealed by the image, or connect totally un-themed words together to still get the fun moment at the end of the puzzle. This post talks about what lead to this feature and has example output.

Show HN: Insquad. Hire startup-ready senior remote developers
text:
Hey. We are pleased to tell you about our startup. Insquad is a Startup-only focused platform to help hire vetted remote developers super-fast and at half the price of a US developer.

Our team is launching Insquad for two reasons:

First - we are startup founders ourselves - we know how it hurts when your best Python Data Scientist quits with a rich offer from corporate. We've been in these shoes before and want to help the startup community succeed.

Second - we've found many incredible software talents that are spread all over the world. Quite often, they can't find a job that matches their level and gives them the opportunity for further growth.

Fortunately, remote reality opens a lot of opportunities to unlock their potential.

As of today

Our product can vet candidates for seniority in 25 major technologies and frameworks and 15 domains of expertise

Soft skills evaluation: startup culture fit, communication, and leadership skills assessment

Hundreds of vetted developers on the platform - all motivated to start working with a US startup

We are developing the product further - adding AI vetting in our process, more skills, enhanced user experience, and some nifty things only startups would appreciate.

https://www.insquad.com/

Tell HN: YouTube prioritises health-related searches 'From health sources'
text:
I only recently noticed this. It may be country-specific. Try searching for a medical condition or health issue. The YouTube search results are labelled 'From health sources'.

I'm not sure what to think of this change. Is it right to remove or deprioritise popular videos from search results if those videos come from unqualified "Doctors". I presume this also apply to anyone discussing a health topic who is not a health professional.

On the other hand, I understand why YouTube has taken this approach. There is a lot of misleading health advice too - it's impossible to police it all. YouTube's approach is to populate search results from health professionals or "credible health sources".

It's a difficult problem to tackle. What do think of this change to YouTube search? Do you think health videos should be unfiltered in search results - no matter the content, or who it comes from?

-----

Some links from YouTube:

Authoritative health information: https://www.youtube.com/howyoutubeworks/product-features/health-information/

Introducing new ways to help you find answers to your health questions: https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/introducing-new-ways-help-you-find-answers-your-health-questions/

Ask HN: Should I go from CamelCase to snake_case for Python wrappers for C++?
text:
I have a data structure which is used in several places:

1. C++: `struct` with CamelCase fields

2. YAML serialization (our file format): dictionaries with CamelCase keys (derived from C++);

3. Documentation: describes the file format, so the same as YAML;

4. Python wrappers: should I stick with CamelCase or convert field names to snake_case?

5. TypeScript wrappers: should I stick with CamelCase or convert field names to dromedaryCase?

I can easily make the conversion, but I suspect it will make it harder to lookup things in the documentation, which would make Python and TypeScript somewhat second class citizens.

On the other hand, if the wrappers do not conform with common practices of the language they are targeting, they feel somewhat second class citizens too.

What do you think?
